title: Understanding the Dopamine Hypothesis
text: The dopamine hypothesis suggests that an overactivity of dopamine neurotransmission in certain brain pathways is linked to the positive symptoms of schizophrenia, such as hallucinations and delusions.

title: Exploring the Glutamate Hypothesis
text: The glutamate hypothesis proposes that a dysfunction in the NMDA receptors on glutamatergic neurons, possibly due to neurodevelopmental issues, contributes to the symptoms of schizophrenia.

title: Serotonin's Role in Schizophrenia
text: The serotonin hypothesis suggests that an overactivity at serotonin receptors may be involved in the development of schizophrenia symptoms.

hintAnswer: that dopamine hyperactivity in the brain’s mesolimbic pathway causes the positive symptoms of schizophrenia; that a hypofunction, formed in the early years of neurodevelopment in the NMDA receptors located on glutamatergic neurons is the cause of schizophrenia; hyperfunction (too much activity) at serotonin receptors
title: Identifying the Three Hypotheses
text: Consider the three main hypotheses: dopamine hyperactivity, glutamate hypofunction, and serotonin hyperfunction. Which of these are considered potential causes of schizophrenia?
